Entries.default: "Captain?"
"Ado, captain."
"HÃ¡jo."
"Greetings again, captain."
"Do you require my expertise?"

"Captain."

Ydwin looks up from a book, her carmine eyes tightening on you.
"Or should I call you 'the Watcher of Caed Nua?' I confess that title something of a mouthful."
"I take it you've heard something of me."
"Caed Nua's gone. It's just captain now."
"Most people just call me 'Watcher.'"
"You can call me [Player Name]."

"Do they? I don't think I'd care for people always calling me 'animancer.'"

She shakes her head.
"No matter. I would hardly want to be like 'most people,' now would I?"

"Captain it is, then."

Her chin raises slightly as she peers through her spectacles.
"How very informal of you."
"I think I would prefer something a bit more... decorous."
"This and that."
"Your involvement in Duc Aevar's hearings on animancy - and the aftermath - brought you to the attention of animancers across the Reach."
"When you took me aboard, you neglected to mention that you were in pursuit of a rampaging deity."
"I'm sorry. I should have told you what was going on."
"Oops."
"I could always leave you back at Neketaka."
"I appreciate the apology, but it's unnecessary."
She chuckles, hiding her mouth behind an open hand.
"No, I think I'd rather you not."
"The blue colossus may be one of the defining events of the age."
"I count myself fortunate to bear witness to your investigation."

"Speaking of, let us return to it, ja?"

She bows slightly at the waist in farewell.
"Do you want to talk about what happened at the Dead Floe?"
"I wanted to ask you about your work as an animancer."
"How did you end up in the Vailian Republics?"
"What do you make of our journey?"
[Leave.] "Maybe another time."
"I admit to excitement. Curiosity. I cherish the opportunity to explore."
"To test my wits against ancient ruins and vicious wildlife."
"Most ships discourage such avocations."
"I appreciate the opportunity to sail the seas. To speak to the people of the Deadfire. To learn."
"It gladdens me, sometimes, to intervene. My past attempts at intercession have been... Less proactive."
"You never cease to amuse, do you?"
"There are too few people like yourself in the world. Thinkers."
"Poor Serafen. He wants so badly to be loved, yet he's terrified of anyone caring for him."
"I certainly do not miss the Land. I imagine that you do not either."

"I understand a harsh choice made towards a necessary end. Gleeful cruelty, however?"

She shakes her head.
"Perhaps some day I will write the history of this. But who would believe it?"
"Magran's Teeth. How few people have ventured that far east? Have set foot on that soil? Exhilarating, isn't it?"
"To walk within the White Void. I've no words."

"Of our alliance with pirates and our ship of the dead? It's certainly does not lack for excitement."

She chuckles over steepled fingers.
"Few are privileged to drive history in matters both scientific and divine. I couldn't ask for more."
"The submersible is truly wondrous. Perhaps we can liberate it from Rauatai."
"The Huana deserve the opportunity to preserve their lands. I do not begrudge you your choice."
"Apologies. I was just thinking of Serafen."
"Given what came of Serafen, I'd rather hold my tongue."
"If I'm to be entirely honest..."
"I sometimes wonder if Serafen wasn't right to leave."
She raises a thin white eyebrow.
"Should I?"
"My studies?"
"I cannot promise a dissertation, but I'll happily discourse upon the broader strokes."
"It was neither so random nor so strange a thing as your question would suggest."
"In a word? Animancy."
"The Republics take the most progressive attitude towards the subject, and thus they attract its foremost scholars."
"Among whom I count myself."

"Meaning herself, of course."

Ydwin smirks at him.
"Of course."
"Did you enjoy the Republics?"
"Why did you leave the Eastern Reach?"
"That's enough for now."

"Of course, captain."

She bows slightly at the waist.
"Increased tensions between the Republics and the Dyrwood, for one."
"I had little interest having my experiments disrupted by some grudge-bearing bricklayer from Defiance Bay."

"I believe you had some hand in that."

She frowns at you.
"Mostly, though, my studies demanded more luminous adra than I could afford to import. So I sought out the source."
"Very much so. Though I imagine you capable of finding someone much better suited to telling you of them."

"I spent most of my time in laboratories and libraries."

She chuckles.
"Then tell me of the laboratories."
"Then tell me of the libraries."
"I admit bias, but they are very likely the grandest in the world." A faint grin lights her wan features.
"Imagine great domes rising above your head, shelves along each wall, stacked high with tomes, as if the building itself were built of bound pages."
"Though I suppose that might sound familiar, given what we found in the Black Isles."
"They were the true treasure of the Republics. The collected histories, dramas, and comedies of Old Vailia. The most advanced arcane theories of Aedyr."
"The most ancient liturgical texts of Engwith and the most advanced treatises on animancy."
"Anything interest you besides studying?"
"In a way, your ship reminds me of them. A dozen kith from every corner of Eora working towards a common goal."
"While your crew pursues Eothas across the sea, ours pursued the future."

"Each chasing our own dawn."

Her nose wrinkles slightly.
"Many things. A strong, dark tea. A comic play. The song of a whale."
"The soft resistance of paper to quill or fabric to needle. Discovering what's just over the horizon."
"There exist things in this world beautiful and wondrous both. One only needs leave the Land to find them."
"Speaking of, let us see what the horizon holds, ja?"
"We spoke with Rymrgand. To his face. Kind of."
"You said something about paying your way to the Republics with coin from a dead man."
"You don't seem to care much for Vatnir."
"Do you still uphold his teachings after seeing the fate of souls bound to him?"
"What is your specific area of study?"
"Any idea how Eothas is moving that statue across the sea?"
"What's so important about luminous adra?"
"What do you hope to do with what you learn?"

"You haven't read my work then?"

She chuckles quietly.
"I'm surprised you haven't read my work." She cocks her head slightly.

"That depends on who you ask."

She shakes her head.
"Generally, adra conducts soul energy. Luminous adra also stores it, however."
"Is it simply a worse conductor, getting clogged by essence? Or is this indicative of a specialized function?"
"Unfortunately, greed stymies inquiry. Rauatai and the Republics grind every ounce they find down into bath salts."
She laughs, a flat palm covering her open mouth.
"I could theorize, but given how little I've observed of him, it would be irresponsible of me to do so."
"It must require incredible energy, though. Staggering amounts of soul essence."

"And can adra truly be so flexible? Why does he not crumble?"

She shakes her head and shrugs.
"Whatever he is, however he accomplishes it, perhaps we can discover together."
"If the discovering doesn't kill us."
"As an apprentice, I focused on - and then helped discredit - the phrenological approach."
"At the time it seemed more difficult than I thought it should be."
"At the time?"
"Why's that?"
"What did you study after?"
"Some of my - colleagues - had a vested interest in a model of the world that included an inherent hierarchy of kith."
"That some kith made more worthy receptacles for souls than others - based on the shape of their brow or the length of their ears - was apparently an idea too tantalizing to abandon."
"Afterwards my interests turned to the theoretical, before shifting a few decades later to the study of parapsychological inertia."
"Individuals engaging in actions or going to places that reflect the experiences of their past lives."
"Pair of what?"
"Let's discuss something else. Anything else."
"Perhaps later. We've work to do, ja?"
"Psychological inertia? As in people thinking the same thing over and over?"

"Just so."

Her grin almost thaws her icy demeanor.
"Close." She nods appraisingly.
"Parapsychological inertia. The tendency for some souls to gravitate towards familiar locales or engage in behaviors exhibited from past lives."
"From there I moved on to work in meta-mortality, the scientific study of souls over lifetimes and the cycle of reincarnation."
"Which brings us to the present."
"You set the sled before the dogs."
"Before making decisions regarding what should be done, we must first understand what is. Anything else is a dream in the dark."
"So what do you hope to learn from your studies?"

"The truth, of course."

Smiling, she opens her palms to you.
"I'm sorry that I have no simple answer for you."

"Embarking on inquiry with an agenda - that is how mistakes get made."

Her arms crossed, Ydwin idly taps on her elbows.
"It sounds as if you speak from experience."
"So you're entirely without bias?"
"Is that how you ended up dead?"
"Not at all. But I admit them."
"I've had a year or two in which to make mistakes."
"You can be a right shit sometimes, Captain Watcher."
She exhales through her nostrils, little more than a quiet sniff, and shakes her head.

"A pleasant diversion as always, captain. Shall we return to work?"

Ydwin turns from you without awaiting an answer.
"Are you surprised? He's a two-faced, manipulative hypocrite."
"And remarkably unpleasant company."
"What's surprising is that anyone bears fondness for him."
"You're not wrong..."
"He's had a rough time. You should take it easy on him."
"He's one of us now. Treat him like it."
"And the smell, right?"

"Show me someone who hasn't."

She shrugs.
"I will treat him with politesse. Provided he does not provoke me."
She smirks.
Ydwin chuckles quietly.
"I'd suggest we take him to the Luminous Bathhouse, but who knows if they'd let him in?"
"I suppose not."
She raises an icy white eyebrow.
"Who, if I recall correctly, you considered selling me to for your own freedom."
"And yet we persist. Remarkable, ja?"

"Perhaps you should seek out another to pass time with, captain."

She bows lightly at the waist and turns from you.
"I hope that you understand what you agreed to, offering to act as his agent."
"He was much as I expected. Cold, hard, both honest and misleading."
"I doubt that it will be easy on your soul."
"Regardless of where the gods came from, I have no doubt that the Land shaped Rymrgand."
"I do. His unpleasantness does not change the fundamental truth of his doctrine."
"I'm glad you maintained your faith."
"The gods aren't real. Their doctrines aren't real."
"Fair enough."
"Speaking of unpleasant, when I asked you to come with me, I thought you'd be nicer."
She blinks, mouth slightly agape.

"Whatever for? Due to my gender? My elf ancestry? The spectacles?"

She crosses her arms, examining you over the rims of her spectacles.
"I am not certain that faith is the right term. But still, I am glad not to have disappointed you?"
"I beg to differ."
"They may be artificial, but they certainly exist."
"Further, they represent philosophies present among the kith prior to the rise of Engwith."
"That a school of thought is blindly followed by some does not entirely negate its validity."
She nods sharply.
"I believe I said I did not want to discuss it."
"If you change your mind, you can talk to me."
"I demand you tell me. I need to know who I travel with."
"Fine, don't tell me."
"I appreciate that, but I assure you that I will not."
"Then you demand that I leave?"
"If it's that important to you, then keep it to yourself, then."
"If you won't answer the question,  you can go."
Her carmine eyes narrow.
"Farewell, captain." After a simple bow, she turns on her heel and walks away.
"I'd like to ask you about your condition."
"My condition?" She scowls.
"If by that you mean the results of my experiment upon the sea, I have no interest in discussing it at this time."
"Or likely ever."
"If you change your mind, you can talk to me."
"I appreciate that, but I assure you that I will not."
"I demand you tell me. I need to know who I travel with."
"Then you demand that I leave?"
"If it's that important to you, then keep it to yourself, then."
"If you won't answer the question,  you can go."
Her carmine eyes narrow.
"Farewell, captain." After a simple bow, she turns on her heel and walks away.
"Fine, don't tell me."
